title: Web Development Basics
subject: Information and Communication Technology (ICT)
introduction: Welcome to the exciting world of web development! Every website you visit‚Äîfrom Google to Facebook to your school's website‚Äîwas built using the technologies you're about to learn. Web development is the skill of creating web pages and applications that run in your browser. In this lesson, you'll discover how the internet works and learn the fundamental building blocks of the web: HTML, CSS, and an introduction to JavaScript.

sections.title: Understanding the Web
sections.content:
Before we start building websites, let's understand what the web actually is and how it works.

**What is the World Wide Web?**
- üåê The web is a system of interconnected documents and resources accessed via the internet
- üì° It uses the internet (the infrastructure) to transfer data between computers
- üîó Web pages are linked together using hyperlinks, creating a 'web' of information
- üåç Invented by Tim Berners-Lee in 1989, it revolutionized how we share information

**How Does the Web Work?**

1. **Client-Server Model**: Your browser (client) requests web pages from web servers
2. **URLs**: Web addresses like `https://www.example.com` tell your browser where to find pages
3. **HTTP/HTTPS**: Protocols that define how data is transferred (HTTPS is secure)
4. **Browsers**: Software like Chrome, Firefox, or Edge that displays web pages
5. **Web Servers**: Powerful computers that store and deliver websites to users

**üá¨üá≠ Real-World Example**: When you visit `www.mtn.com.gh`, your browser sends a request to MTN's web server in Ghana. The server sends back HTML, CSS, and JavaScript files, which your browser displays as the MTN website.

Now that you understand the basics, here are some best practices and resources to continue your web development journey. **Web Development Best Practices:** - ‚úÖ **Write Clean Code**: Use proper indentation and meaningful names - ‚úÖ **Comment Your Code**: Explain complex sections for yourself and others - ‚úÖ **Keep Files Organized**: Use separate folders for CSS, JavaScript, and images - ‚úÖ **Test on Multiple Browsers**: Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge - ‚úÖ **Make It Responsive**: Ensure your site works on phones, tablets, and desktops - ‚úÖ **Optimize Images**: Compress images for faster loading - ‚úÖ **Use External CSS/JS**: Don't put styles and scripts inline - ‚úÖ **Validate Your HTML**: Use W3C Validator to check for errors - ‚úÖ **Accessibility**: Make sure everyone can use your site (alt text for images, proper headings) **Common Mistakes to Avoid:** - ‚ùå Forgetting to close tags: `
